context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Suze Orman says this is the 'new retirement age'
context_meta.summary: You may have to work longer than you were planning to, warns personal finance expert Suze Orman.

text: She is (unfortunately) right.  Our "2% inflation" is a laugh because in the real world it is really 8% or more.  And if 8% is the REAL number, in 9 years the price of everything would be twice what things cost today.  If wages only rise by the 2% COLA increases that most employers give (if you're lucky) then you better plan on working til your AT LEAST 70.  This assumed that all your kids are done with school and on their own and you can have 15-20 years to sock away money.  Think about it. If you are now 60 and need $ 1 million to retire today, you'll need $2 million at age 70. So between investments and additional income you'd have to be able to put away an average $100k/year- just to stay even in terms of standard of living. Now, I've oversimplified, because many of us have paid off mortgages. But many of us refinanced. And most of us are victims of unabated property tax increases and additional taxation that comes with inflation.  The last 10 years of sub-1% interest foisted on us by the Federal Reserve has decimated our "safe cash".  It changed the entire retirement picture for those over 50.  The geniuses in Washington have screwed us over and not a whimper in the press.  They'd rather bash Trump for his hair, his hat, his wife, his kids because it's more fun for them.  Sadly, they fail to recognize it they're in the trick-trap with us too.

context_meta.summary: Creating a financial strategy is like planning a vacation. First, you need to take care of the mundane details, including shopping for hotel accommodations and plane fares, as well as preparing your itinerary. While these tasks may be tedious, the time spent planning is well worth the effort once you are enjoying your vacation. Developing a financial plan is a similar process. First, you must determine where you want to go and then, how to get there. Otherwise, you may encounter problems or even get financially “lost” along the way. However, with a financial road map in hand, you may feel more confident that you are headed in the right direction. You may also be better equipped to adapt to changing

context_meta.summary: Forget about leaving the workforce at age 63. "70 is the new retirement age," personal finance maven Suze Orman writes on Money. "Not a month or year before." She points out that Americans are living longer, meaning your retirement savings need to last longer: "You likely have plenty saved up to breeze through 15 years or so of retirement. But, people, if you stop working in your 60s, your retirement stash might need to support you for 30 years, not 15." Plus, health care costs add up, she notes. Fidelity estimates that a healthy, 65-year-old couple retiring in 2017 will need a whopping $275,000 to cover their health care costs in retirement. context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: JPMorgan reaches beyond its branches with new mobile account app
context_meta.summary: In its first offering of online bank accounts, JPMorgan Chase & Co on Monday launched a new smartphone app that it hopes will attract new depositors, many of whom are young and may live far from any of its branch offices. FILE PHOTO: People pass the JP Morgan Chase & Co. Corporate headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, May 20, 2015. The app, named Finn by Chase, allows people to use a phone to open a bank account, make deposits, issue checks, track spending and set up savings plans, bank officials told Reuters last week. The bank is starting with an initial test of the app account for Apple phone users with ZIP codes in St. Louis, where Chase has no branches, which might influence the trial.

context_meta.summary: Your house might be decorated with carved pumpkins and creepy cobwebs, but before you know it, it will be Christmas again. And now is the right time to hash out your holiday gifts game plan, personal finance experts say. There are two reasons for that, Scott Hannah, head of the Credit Counselling Society, told Global News. The first is that you'll need some time to draw up a budget. The second is that tackling your gift list with plenty of lead time means you'll have more opportunity to snatch deals, including on Black Friday and Cyber Monday. Buying early also means you can pick the slower – and cheaper – shipping options without worry. Above all, said Hanna, avoid last-minute “panic shopping,”

context_meta.title: Corporate Bonds: What To Consider Before Investing
context_meta.summary: Corporate bonds are a popular option for many investors, offering an alternative - and generally more lucrative - way to invest in business compared to buying shares. Corporate bonds are essentially an IOU from a business - they want to borrow some money, and turn to investors to deliver that funding, paying back interest on that debt at half-yearly intervals before returning the capital when the bond matures. While some corporate bonds are made available to retail investors, many are restricted solely to institutional investors, though that is changing thanks to WiseAlpha, an investment platform which opens up bonds from some of the biggest brands to normal investors.
